items.description: Analyze repository structure and document all modules, directories, configuration files, and their purposes
items.acceptance_criteria: A written document (repo_analysis.md) listing every file/directory in the repo, its purpose, and how modules interconnect. Must cover .gitattributes (LFS config), .gitignore, TASK_orchestrator.md, figures/, results/ directories.
items.notes: Created repo_analysis.md covering all files, directories, configurations, and module interconnections.

items.description: Formalize the research problem: define Beatty sequences, homogeneous linear recurrences (C-finite sequences), and state the precise characterization question
items.acceptance_criteria: A file problem_statement.md containing: (1) rigorous definition of floor(n*r) for real r>0, (2) definition of a homogeneous linearly recurrent sequence (a(n) = c_1*a(n-1)+...+c_k*a(n-k)), (3) precise formulation distinguishing 'the full sequence is C-finite' from 'contains an infinite C-finite subsequence', (4) clarification of whether 'subsequence' means indexed by an increasing sequence of natural numbers or a contiguous block.
items.notes: Created problem_statement.md with rigorous definitions, formal problem statement, and conjectured answer.

items.description: Conduct comprehensive literature search via web for Beatty sequences, Sturmian words, C-finite sequences, and their intersections
items.acceptance_criteria: Web searches performed for at least the following topics: (a) 'Beatty sequence linear recurrence', (b) 'Sturmian word C-finite subsequence', (c) 'Fraenkel iterated floor function algebraic', (d) 'Wythoff array Fibonacci recurrence', (e) 'Ostrowski numeration automatic sequence', (f) 'Skolem-Mahler-Lech theorem floor sequences', (g) 'Ballot Beatty compositions linear recurrence 2017', (h) 'Schaeffer Shallit Zorcic decidability quadratic 2024'. Results documented in literature_review.md with paper titles, authors, years, key theorems, and relevance assessment.
items.notes: All 8 searches performed plus 3 additional. Created literature_review.md with 16 paper reviews and taxonomy.

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted sources
items.acceptance_criteria: File sources.bib in the repo root contains valid BibTeX entries for at least 15 relevant papers. Must include entries for: Fraenkel 1994 (iterated floor functions), Ballot 2017 (JIS paper on Beatty compositions), Schaeffer-Shallit-Zorcic 2024 (arXiv:2402.08331), Allouche-Shallit 2003 (Automatic Sequences book), Hieronymi-Terry 2018 (Ostrowski numeration), Cassaigne (recurrence in infinite words), Russo-Schwiebert 2011 (Fibonacci Quarterly), Kimberling 2011 (generalized Wythoff), Tijdeman 2000 (Fraenkel conjecture), and at least 6 additional relevant sources found during the search.
items.notes: sources.bib populated with 21 BibTeX entries covering all required papers plus additional references.

items.description: Synthesize literature into a taxonomy: classify known results by type of r (rational, quadratic irrational, higher-degree algebraic, transcendental with bounded CF, general irrational)
items.acceptance_criteria: A section in literature_review.md with a table/matrix summarizing for each class of r: (a) whether floor(n*r) is itself C-finite, (b) whether it is known to contain a C-finite subsequence, (c) key references, (d) whether a complete characterization exists. Must identify gaps in the literature and explicitly state which cases remain open.
items.notes: Taxonomy table included in literature_review.md with 6 classes of r, gap analysis, and revised conjectures A and B.

items.description: Identify the conjectured characterization and key proof strategies from the literature
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proof_strategy.md outlining: (1) the conjectured answer (floor(n*r) contains an infinite homogeneous C-finite subsequence if and only if r is rational or a quadratic irrational -- or a broader/narrower conjecture if evidence warrants), (2) proof strategies for the 'if' direction (constructive, using Wythoff-type arrays, iterated compositions, or Ostrowski automata), (3) proof strategies for the 'only if' direction (using equidistribution, transcendence properties, or non-automaticity arguments), (4) identification of Ballot's open Problems 36-37 and Fraenkel's related conjectures as key obstacles.
items.notes: Created proof_strategy.md with conjectured characterization, proof strategies for both directions, and discussion of Ballot's open problems and the cubic obstruction.

items.description: Implement a Python module to compute Beatty sequences floor(n*r) for arbitrary real r, supporting exact arithmetic for rationals and quadratic irrationals
items.acceptance_criteria: A file beatty.py that: (1) computes floor(n*r) for n=1..N given r as a rational (Fraction), a quadratic irrational (a+b*sqrt(d) form), or a float, (2) returns a list/array of integers, (3) includes unit tests verifying known values (e.g., floor(n*phi) for n=1..20 matches OEIS A000201), (4) handles N up to 10^6 efficiently (< 5 seconds).
items.notes: beatty.py implemented with QuadraticIrrational class, exact isqrt arithmetic, numpy float path. All tests pass, N=10^6 in 0.57s.

items.description: Implement a module to detect and fit homogeneous linear recurrences from integer sequences using the Berlekamp-Massey algorithm
items.acceptance_criteria: A file recurrence_detector.py that: (1) given a finite integer sequence, finds the minimal-order homogeneous linear recurrence satisfied by the sequence (if one exists up to a given order bound), (2) uses Berlekamp-Massey or equivalent algorithm, (3) validates the recurrence on held-out terms, (4) unit tests pass on known C-finite sequences (Fibonacci, tribonacci, geometric) and correctly reports 'no recurrence found' for random/non-recurrent input.
items.notes: recurrence_detector.py with Berlekamp-Massey algorithm using exact Fraction arithmetic. 28/28 tests pass.

items.description: Implement subsequence extraction: given a Beatty sequence and a selection rule (arithmetic progression of indices, iterated composition, etc.), extract and return the subsequence
items.acceptance_criteria: A file subsequence_extractor.py that: (1) extracts subsequences of floor(n*r) indexed by arithmetic progressions a+b*k for k=0,1,..., (2) extracts iterated compositions (e.g., floor(floor(floor(n*r)*r)*r)...), (3) extracts subsequences along Wythoff-type paths, (4) unit tests verify that for r=phi, the Wythoff row starting at 1 produces Fibonacci numbers.
items.notes: subsequence_extractor.py with 4 strategies (AP, iterated comp, iterated a-comp, Wythoff rows). All tests pass. Wythoff row 1 for phi = [1,2,3,5,8,13,21].

items.description: Build baseline experimental pipeline: for a given r, systematically search for C-finite subsequences within floor(n*r) across multiple extraction strategies
items.acceptance_criteria: A file baseline_pipeline.py that: (1) takes r as input, (2) computes floor(n*r) for n=1..N, (3) applies all extraction strategies from item_009, (4) runs recurrence_detector on each extracted subsequence, (5) reports all discovered recurrences with their orders, characteristic polynomials, and the extraction method used, (6) outputs results as JSON to results/ directory. Tested on r=3/2 (rational), r=phi (quadratic), r=pi (transcendental).
items.notes: Pipeline finds 41 recurrences for rational, 16 for phi (including order-2 Fibonacci in all Wythoff rows), 2 trivial for pi.

items.description: Define quantitative metrics for measuring recurrence quality and subsequence density
items.acceptance_criteria: Document metrics.md defining: (1) recurrence order (lower is stronger), (2) length of verified prefix before recurrence breaks (if it does), (3) density of the subsequence within the original sequence (proportion of indices used), (4) spectral radius of the companion matrix (growth rate). Implement metric computation in metrics.py with unit tests.
items.notes: metrics.md defines 4 metrics. metrics.py implements all with 6 passing tests including Fibonacci and Pell spectral radii.

items.description: Prove the 'if' direction for rational r: show that floor(n*r) is itself C-finite when r is rational
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proofs/rational_case.md containing a complete, self-contained proof that for r=p/q in lowest terms, floor(n*r) satisfies the linear recurrence a(n+q) = a(n) + p. Proof must include: (1) derivation from the identity floor((n+q)*p/q) = floor(n*p/q) + p, (2) explicit characteristic polynomial x^q - 1 (after differencing) with roots as q-th roots of unity, (3) verification that this is homogeneous after appropriate rewriting, (4) worked example for r=3/2.

items.description: Prove the 'if' direction for quadratic irrationals: construct explicit C-finite subsequences of floor(n*r) when r is a quadratic irrational
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proofs/quadratic_case.md containing: (1) proof that for any quadratic irrational r with minimal polynomial ax^2+bx+c=0, the Beatty sequence floor(n*r) contains an infinite subsequence satisfying a homogeneous linear recurrence, (2) at least two independent constructions: (a) via the Wythoff array / complementary Beatty pair method (showing rows satisfy a second-order recurrence related to the minimal polynomial of r), (b) via Ballot's iterated composition method, (3) explicit worked examples for r=phi=(1+sqrt(5))/2, r=1+sqrt(2), and r=(1+sqrt(3))/2, (4) statement and proof that the recurrence order relates to the degree of the minimal polynomial of r. All proofs must be unconditional (no unverified conjectures relied upon).

items.description: Attack the 'only if' direction: prove that if r is irrational and not a quadratic irrational, then floor(n*r) contains no infinite homogeneous C-finite subsequence
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proofs/only_if_direction.md containing: (1) a rigorous argument (or identification of the precise obstruction if a full proof is not achievable) showing that for non-quadratic irrationals, no infinite subsequence of floor(n*r) can satisfy a homogeneous linear recurrence, (2) the argument must address both algebraic irrationals of degree >= 3 and transcendentals separately, (3) key techniques used must include at least two of: equidistribution mod 1, non-automaticity of floor(n*r), growth rate analysis via Skolem-Mahler-Lech, properties of the Ostrowski representation, (4) if a complete proof is not achieved, the file must contain a precise conditional statement identifying the gap and what additional result would close it. Cite at least 5 papers from sources.bib.

items.description: Investigate the boundary case: irrationals with bounded continued fraction partial quotients that are not quadratic
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proofs/bounded_cf_case.md containing: (1) analysis of whether badly approximable transcendental numbers (bounded CF coefficients) can yield C-finite subsequences, (2) computational experiments on specific examples (e.g., Euler-type continued fractions [1,2,1,1,4,1,1,6,...] for e, or explicitly constructed badly-approximable transcendentals), (3) a theorem or strong heuristic argument distinguishing these from quadratic irrationals, (4) connection to whether the morphic/non-morphic nature of the Sturmian word is the key discriminator, citing Allouche-Shallit 2003.

items.description: Develop a unified characterization theorem synthesizing the rational, quadratic, and non-quadratic cases
items.acceptance_criteria: A file proofs/main_theorem.md containing: (1) precise statement of the Main Theorem: 'The sequence floor(n*r) (n=1,2,3,...) contains an infinite homogeneous linearly recurrent subsequence if and only if r is rational or a quadratic irrational', (2) a proof outline showing how the rational case (item_012), quadratic case (item_013), and only-if direction (item_014) combine, (3) discussion of whether 'homogeneous' is essential or if the result extends to inhomogeneous recurrences, (4) explicit statement of all lemmas used with cross-references to the supporting proof files. If the 'only if' direction has a gap, the theorem must be stated conditionally with the gap clearly identified.

items.description: Systematic computational experiments on rational r: verify C-finite property for r=p/q with 1 <= p,q <= 20
items.acceptance_criteria: Results saved to results/rational_experiments.json containing for each tested r=p/q: (1) the detected recurrence order and coefficients, (2) verification that order equals q (denominator) after reduction, (3) characteristic polynomial. All 190+ test cases pass (detected recurrence matches theoretical prediction from item_012). Summary statistics in results/rational_summary.md.

items.description: Systematic computational experiments on quadratic irrationals: test r = (a+b*sqrt(d))/c for small parameters
items.acceptance_criteria: Results saved to results/quadratic_experiments.json covering at least 30 distinct quadratic irrationals (including phi, sqrt(2), sqrt(3), (1+sqrt(5))/2, (1+sqrt(d))/2 for d=2,3,5,6,7,8,10,...,50). For each: (1) at least one C-finite subsequence found, (2) recurrence order and coefficients reported, (3) extraction method that found it recorded, (4) comparison of recurrence characteristic roots to algebraic conjugates of r as predicted by theory (item_013). Generate figure figures/quadratic_recurrence_orders.png plotting recurrence order vs discriminant d.

items.description: Systematic computational experiments on non-quadratic irrationals: test algebraic irrationals of degree >= 3 and common transcendentals
items.acceptance_criteria: Results saved to results/non_quadratic_experiments.json covering at least 15 non-quadratic irrationals: (1) algebraic of degree 3 (e.g., 2^(1/3), root of x^3-x-1), (2) algebraic of degree 4+, (3) transcendentals (pi, e, ln(2), sqrt(2)+sqrt(3), Liouville number). For each, the pipeline must search exhaustively (all extraction strategies from item_009 with sequence length N >= 10^5) and report: either a discovered recurrence (unexpected, would challenge the conjecture) or 'no C-finite subsequence found' with the search parameters used. If any recurrence is found for a non-quadratic irrational, flag it prominently for manual verification.

items.description: Stress-test the boundary: experiments on irrationals with bounded vs unbounded continued fraction coefficients
items.acceptance_criteria: Results saved to results/cf_boundary_experiments.json testing: (1) at least 5 quadratic irrationals (bounded CF by Lagrange), (2) at least 5 non-quadratic irrationals with bounded CF (constructed explicitly or from known examples), (3) at least 5 irrationals with unbounded CF (e.g., e, whose CF is [2;1,2,1,1,4,1,1,6,...]). For bounded-CF non-quadratics, document whether any C-finite subsequences are found. Include figures/cf_boundary_comparison.png comparing results across the three groups.

items.description: Validate all computational findings against prior work cited in sources.bib
items.acceptance_criteria: A file results/validation_report.md that: (1) cross-checks all Fibonacci-related findings for r=phi against Russo-Schwiebert 2011 and Kimberling 2011, (2) verifies Wythoff array recurrences against standard OEIS entries (A000201, A001950, A003622), (3) checks iterated composition results against Ballot 2017 (Table 1 and Theorem 30), (4) confirms decidability predictions from Schaeffer-Shallit-Zorcic 2024 where applicable, (5) reports any discrepancies found.

items.description: Write a complete proof document consolidating all results into a single self-contained paper
items.acceptance_criteria: A file paper.md (or paper.tex) containing: (1) Abstract summarizing the main result, (2) Introduction with motivation and history, (3) Preliminaries defining all notation, (4) Main Theorem with complete proof (or clearest possible conditional statement), (5) Supporting lemmas with full proofs, (6) Computational evidence section, (7) Conclusion discussing open questions. Must cite at least 15 entries from sources.bib. Total length at least 3000 words.

items.description: Create comprehensive figures illustrating the characterization
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 4 figures in figures/ directory: (1) figures/beatty_examples.png showing floor(n*r) for representative r values (rational, quadratic, transcendental), (2) figures/recurrence_detection.png illustrating how a C-finite subsequence is extracted from a quadratic-irrational Beatty sequence, (3) figures/characterization_venn.png showing the Venn diagram of real numbers classified by the theorem, (4) figures/cf_vs_recurrence.png showing the relationship between continued fraction structure and recurrence existence. All figures must have proper axis labels and legends.

items.description: Document all code with docstrings, type hints, and a README explaining how to reproduce all experiments
items.acceptance_criteria: Updated README.md containing: (1) project description and main result, (2) installation instructions (Python version, dependencies), (3) instructions to reproduce each experiment from Phase 4, (4) description of each Python module. All .py files must have module-level docstrings and function-level docstrings with type hints. A requirements.txt file listing all dependencies.

items.description: Perform a gap analysis: identify any remaining gaps in the proof and document them as open problems
items.acceptance_criteria: A file open_problems.md containing: (1) if the proof is complete and unconditional, a statement certifying this with a self-check of each logical step, (2) if gaps remain, a precise enumeration of each gap with (a) what is assumed but not proved, (b) what known results or conjectures might close the gap, (c) suggested approaches, (3) discussion of extensions: does the characterization change for inhomogeneous recurrences? For floor(n*r + s) with s != 0? For higher-dimensional analogs? Must reference Ballot's open problems 36-37 and assess whether the work resolves them.

items.description: Final review: verify logical consistency of all proofs, correctness of all experiments, and completeness of documentation
items.acceptance_criteria: A file review_checklist.md with a signed-off checklist confirming: (1) every lemma is either proved or has a citation, (2) every experimental claim is backed by reproducible code and saved results, (3) sources.bib contains >= 15 entries and all cited works are referenced in the paper, (4) the main theorem statement is precise and unambiguous, (5) the paper is self-contained (a reader with graduate-level math background can follow the entire argument), (6) no circular reasoning exists in the proof chain.
